subsection.title: Introduction
subsection.p: The absolute value function is used to model problems involving distance. Recall that the absolute value of a number gives the distance from the origin to that number on the number line.

assemblage.title: Distance and Absolute Value
assemblage.p: The distance between two points x and a is given by \abs{x - a}.

subsection.p: For example, the equation \abs{x - 2} = 6 means "the distance between x and 2 is 6 units." The number x could be to the left or the right of 2 on the number line. Thus, the equation has two solutions, 8 and -4, as shown below.

statement.p:
Write each statement using absolute value notation. Illustrate the solutions on a number line.
x is three units from the origin.
p is two units from 5.
a is within four units of -2.

solution.p:
First, restate each statement in terms of distance.
The distance between x and the origin is three units, or \abs{x} = 3. Thus, x can be 3 or -3. absolut value of x is 3
The distance between p and 5 is two units, or \abs{p - 5} = 2. If we count two units on either side of 5, we see that p can be 3 or 7. absolut value of p-5 is 2
The distance between a and -2 is less than four units, or \abs{a - (-2)} \lt 4, or \abs{a + 2} \lt 4. Count four units on either side of -2, to find -6 and 2. Then a is between -6 and 2, or -6 \lt a \lt 2. 4 units from -2

subsection.title: Absolute Value Equations
subsection.p: We can use distances on a number line to solve simple equations such as \abs{3x - 6} = 9 First, we factor out the coefficient of x, to get \abs{3(x - 2)} = 9. Because of the multiplicative property of the absolute value, namely that \abs{ab} = \abs{a}\abs{b}, we can write the left side as \begin{aligned}[t] \abs{3}\abs{x - 2} \amp = 9 \\ 3\abs{x - 2} \amp= 9 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 3.}}\\ \abs{x - 2} \amp = 3 \end{aligned} which tells us that the distance between x and 2 is 3 units, so the solutions are x = -1 and x = 5.

stack.p: Alternatively, we can use graphs when working with absolute values. For example, we know that the simple equation \abs{x} = 5 has two solutions, x = 5 and x = -5.
In fact, we can see from the graph at right that the equation \abs{x} = k has two solutions if k \gt 0, one solution if k = 0, and no solution if k \lt 0.

li.p: Use a graph of y = \abs{3x - 6} to solve the equation \abs{3x - 6} = 9.
Use a graph of y = \abs{3x - 6} to solve the equation \abs{3x - 6} = -2.
There are no points on the graph of y = \abs{3x - 6} with y = -2, so the equation \abs{3x - 6} = -2 has no solutions.

subsection.p: To solve an absolute value equation algebraically, we use the definition of absolute value.
In general, we have the following strategy for solving absolute value equations.

assemblage.title: Absolute Value Equations
assemblage.p: The equation \abs{ax + b} = c \hphantom{break} (c \gt 0) is equivalent to ax + b = c ~~\text{ or }~~ ax + b = -c

subsection.title: Absolute Value Inequalities
subsection.p: We can also use graphs to solve absolute value inequalities. Look again at the graph of y = \abs{3x - 6} in figure (a) below.

Because of the V-shape of the graph, all points with y-values less than 9 lie between the two solutions of ~\abs{3x - 6} = 9~, that is, between -1 and 5. Thus, the solutions of the inequality ~\abs{3x - 6} \lt 9~ are -1 \lt x \lt 5. (In the Homework Problems, you will be asked to show this algebraically.)

On the other hand, to solve the inequality ~\abs{3x - 6} \gt 9~, we look for points on the graph with y-values greater than 9. In figure (b), we see that these points have x-values outside the interval between -1 and 5. In other words, the solutions of the inequality ~\abs{3x - 6} \gt 9~ are x \lt -1 or x \gt 5.
Thus, we can solve an absolute value inequality by first solving the related equation.

assemblage.title: Absolute Value Inequalities
assemblage.p:
Suppose the solutions of the equation \abs{ax+b}=c are r and s, with r \lt s. Then
The solutions of ~\abs{ax+b} \lt c~ are r \lt x \lt s
The solutions of ~\abs{ax+b} \gt c~ are x \lt r ~~\text{ or }~~ x \gt s

subsection.title: Measurement Error
subsection.p: If you weigh a sample in chemistry lab, the scale’s digital readout might show 6.0 grams. But it is unlikely that the sample weighs exactly 6 grams; there is always some error in measured values.

Because the scale shows the weight as 6.0 grams, we know that the true weight of the sample must be between 5.95 grams and 6.05 grams: If the weight were less than 5.95 grams, the scale would round down to 5.9 grams, and if the weight were more than 6.05 grams, the scale would round up to 6.1 grams. We should report the mass of the sample as 6 \pm 0.05 grams, which tells the reader that the error in the measurement is no more than 0.05 grams.

We can also describe this measurement error, or error toleranceerror tolerance, using an absolute value inequality. Because the measured mass m can be no more than 0.05 from 6, we write \abs{m - 6} \le 0.05 Note that the solution of this inequality is 5.95 \le m \le 6.05.
